PREFACE

THE title of this volume—a translation of the Latin words “Legenda Aurea '’—recalls the custom in medieval churches and monasteries of gathering into a large volume records of the lives and deaths of saintly personageS, and reading them aloud according as the ecclesiastical year brought round their memorial days, The reading due on a particular day would be the “legenda'' (scilicet “ lectio '') 3 and from it the whole volume would be entitled the “ legendarium '' or (more simply) the “legenda’' From the narra- tive character of these readingS, which naturally made a considerable impression on the popular mind, the modern word “legend ’' gained its circulation and meaning3 that its meaning has somewhat deteriorated, implying fiction rather than fact, is not surprising3 a similar fate besell our word “ story ” and the F rench “ histoire.''

The “ legendae '' of particular churches or monas— teries would naturally be of local and limited scope. The thirteenth century—an age of mental awakening —demanded something of wider range.
